title: Sans with contrasting stroke
content:
Hi, I’m working on some packaging design for a food company. I need a find a font which will be used for all product names (varying from diary, meat and fruit) to make it consistent. The concept is healthy low fat products. I am currently thinking of semi sans or a rounded sans, brush scripts or maybe a soft serif with swash caps. Any suggestions to what might fit?

Oystein

 [‹ Times New Roman's many versions!](http://web.archive.org/web/20080324121457/http:/typophile.com/node/39087 "Go to previous forum topic") [Help Identifying the GILBERT PAPER face... ›](http://web.archive.org/web/20080324121457/http:/typophile.com/node/39413 "Go to next forum topic")
author: oystein

comments.content: There are some ideas in our features on [packaging fonts](http://web.archive.org/web/20080324121457/http:/www.fontshop.com/fontfeed/archives/in-use-more-packaging-fonts/) and [soft scripts](http://web.archive.org/web/20080324121457/http:/www.fontshop.com/features/newsletters/sep2006_a/).

Try checking out [http://www.sudtipos.com/home](http://web.archive.org/web/20080324121457/http:/www.sudtipos.com/home "http://www.sudtipos.com/home"). They have a great selection of floaty, swashy fonts that aren’t too fussy. Approachable.

I’ve seen the feature on the packaging fonts, but not the soft scripts. Thanks, they are great resources Stephen! Thats where I got some inspiration for direction. I also checked out Sudtipos, and found Amorinda worth considering. I’ll keep searching.
